Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Collaborative Research: The Origin and Diversification of Hearing in Malagasy-South Asian Cichlids
Award.AbstractNarration: This project comprises a series of interdisciplinary studies of the functional evolution of hearing in cichlid fishes. Cichlids are freshwater fishes that often serve as model organisms for evolutionary and behavioral studies. Although it is not widely known, the Malagasy and South Asian (but not the African or Neotropical) cichlids exhibit modifications of the ear, skull and gas bladder, which create a direct mechanical linkage between the gas bladder and inner ear. Similar structures in other fishes are known to bestow enhanced hearing ability. A high degree of variability of these structures in cichlids suggests that hearing abilities have evolved and diversified within this group of fishes, and provides us a uniquely powerful model system to explore the origin of a new sensory ability and the subsequent evolutionary diversification of a new sense. This collaborative project combines comparative morphological studies of accessory hearing structures with experimental studies of hearing ability using neurophysiological techniques. Field and laboratory studies will document the diversity of hearing ability and correlate differences in perceptual ability with anatomical and ecological features. Malagasy-South Asian cichlids present an ideal case to test the hypothesis that new sensory systems evolve in low-noise habitats to exploit new sensory opportunities, rather than evolving in high-noise habitats to conserve function in the face of increased noise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to better understand how enhanced hearing evolves in a group of fishes that exhibit considerable anatomical variation in hearing-related structures. We hypothesized that the variation we observed in cichlids, specifically in the anterior region of the gas bladder and posterior portion of the skull, would correlate with variation in hearing ability, such that species with a direct mechanical linkage between the gas bladder and the inner ear would exhibit more sensitive hearing.

To address this hypothesis, we conducted a series of interdisciplinary studies to relate physiological measures of hearing function with three-dimensional reconstructions of gas bladder and inner ear morphology.

Unlike their African and Neotropical counterparts, Malagasy-South Asian cichlids exhibit numerous modifications of the anterior gas bladder and the posterior portion of the skull, which in Paretroplus and Etroplus, comprising the subfamily Etroplinae, includes an intracranial bulla directly apposed to the inner ear. We hypothesized that specialized hearing had evolved within this group of cichlids, and that the observed anatomical variation would provide for a wide range of enhanced hearing abilities for species in which the anterior gas bladder has evolved paired extensions, or diverticula, that are in close proximity with the inner ear. The Malagasy-South Asian cichlids were ideal for such a study as their evolutionary relationships are well understood and, therefore, we could interpret our findings in the context of a robust hypothesis of relationships. The diversity of structural modifications observed in this assemblage provides a unique model system for the study of the origins and diversification of hearing.

We have demonstrated a very strong correlation between degree of development of the anterior gas bladder diverticula and enhanced hearing ability. Those taxa with a more complex and well-developed connection (i.e., the anterior diverticula of the gas bladder penetrate the exoccipital region of the skull and are closely apposed to the inner ear) exhibit increased auditory sensitivity and a wider range of detectable frequencies than fishes in which the anterior gas bladder extensions only approach or abut the posterior region of the skull, and far better than those lacking anterior extensions of the gas bladder. We see a very clear progression in hearing ability that is strongly correlated with proximity of the anterior gas bladder diverticula and the inner ear.

Achieving our research objectives required multiple field expeditions to Madagascar, and we have trained a number of students and postdoctoral researchers from both the US and Madagascar in various aspects of this project, both in the laboratory and in the field. Our results are the first to analyze the evolution of hearing in a group of fishes within an evolutionary framework and are broadly applicable to related studies of hearing evolution in other animal groups.
